title: 104_s1448
content: The "Gay and Lesbian Youth Suicide Prevention Act" establishes the National Commission on Gay and Lesbian Youth Suicide Prevention. The National Commission on Gay and Lesbian Youth Suicide Prevention is composed of 31 members appointed by the Secretary of Health and Human Services, including professionals in youth suicide prevention. Members serve for the life of the Commission, advise the Department of Health and Human Services, and a chairperson is selected by the Secretary. The National Commission on Gay and Lesbian Youth Suicide Prevention aims to combat the high rate of suicide among this demographic, advising federal and state agencies on including their concerns in prevention policies and programs. The National Commission on Gay and Lesbian Youth Suicide Prevention advises Federal and State agencies on addressing the epidemic of youth suicide among the LGBTQ+ community by expanding research and amending existing policies to include appropriate guidelines for gay and lesbian youth. The National Commission on Gay and Lesbian Youth Suicide Prevention conducts regional public hearings to gather information and prepares interim and final reports for the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 6. The National Commission on Gay and Lesbian Youth Suicide Prevention has powers outlined in Section 6, which include obtaining information from Federal agencies, using postal services, and accepting voluntary services. Commission personnel matters are addressed in Section 7. Members of the Commission serve without compensation but are allowed travel expenses. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. The Chairperson can procure temporary services as needed. Individuals can receive compensation up to the annual rate of basic pay for level V of the Executive Schedule. The Commission will terminate 6 months after its first meeting.
